Rembrandt.passage: Rembrandt Harmenszoon van Rijn (1606–1669) was a Dutch painter, draughtsman, and printmaker. He is generally considered one of the most important figures in art history. Born in Leiden, Rembrandt began his career as a portrait painter, but soon turned to landscape painting and then to the art of etching. He was influenced by the work of Italian artists, particularly in the use of chiaroscuro, and his paintings exhibit an extensive knowledge of anatomy, light, and shadow. In 1632, he moved to Amsterdam, where he spent the rest of his life. In 1648, he was bankrupt, and his possessions were sold to pay his debts. Despite this setback, Rembrandt continued to produce great works, including The Night Watch and The Mill. He also created numerous drawings and etchings, many of which were posthumously published. His work was admired by contemporaries and influential artists, such as Peter Paul Rubens and Claude Lorrain, and his style was emulated by many painters, such as Gianlorenzo Bernini and Caravaggio. Rembrandt's innovative and expressive style, which combined strong emotion and dramatic lighting, had a profound impact on the course of art history. His portraits, landscapes, and narrative paintings are considered masterpieces, and his prints have had an enduring influence on generations of artists.

Francisco Goya.passage: Francisco Goya (30 March 1746 – 16 April 1798) was a Spanish painter and printmaker. He is considered one of the most important figures in art history. Goya was born in Fuendetodos, Aragon, to a family of modest means. He moved to Madrid to pursue his artistic career, and soon established himself as a painter of religious and historical themes. During his lifetime, he created numerous works that were critical of the Spanish government and the Catholic Church, which led to his being named a 'discoverer of truth' by his contemporaries. His style, which shifted from the early tenebrism to the later, more optimistic style known as 'sunshine painting,' was influential on numerous artists, such as Vincent van Gogh and Francisco de Zurbarán. Goya's later works, known as the Black Paintings, were painted on the walls and ceilings of his house in Madrid, and are some of the most famous works in the history of art. These works, characterized by their bleakness and focus on human suffering, were not publicly recognized until after his death. Goya died in 1798, and his remains were moved to the Royal Chapel of San Lorenzo de El Escorial in 1819. His work continues to influence art, film, and literature, and his paintings are celebrated for their psychological insight, expressive brushwork, and boldness in addressing contemporary social and political issues.

Jackson Pollock.passage: Jackson Pollock (born January 28, 1912, in Cody, Wyoming; died August 12, 1956, in an automobile accident in Springs, New York) was an influential American painter and a major figure in the abstract expressionist movement. He was well known for his drip painting technique, which involved pouring paint onto a canvas laid on the ground, and for his turbulent and chaotic artistic style. Pollock's artistic career began in the 1930s when he studied under Thomas Hart Benton at the Art Students League of New York. There, he learned about mural painting and developed an interest in social realism. In 1938, Pollock had his first solo exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art (MoMA) in New York. The following year, he joined the Federal Art Project, a New Deal program that employed artists during the Great Depression. In 1942, Pollock met the artist Lee Krasner, whom he married in 1945. The couple moved to Long Island, where they shared a studio. It was during this time that Pollock began experimenting with his drip painting technique. In 1947, he had his first solo exhibition at the Betty Parsons Gallery in New York, which featured his new works. The exhibition established Pollock as a leading figure in the abstract expressionist movement. In 1950, Pollock's painting Convergence was featured in the landmark exhibition 15 Americans at the Museum of Modern Art. The following year, he was awarded a Guggenheim Fellowship, which allowed him to work on large-scale paintings.

Andy Warhol.passage: Andy Warhol (August 6, 1928 – February 22, 1987) was an American artist, director, and producer who was a leading figure in the visual art movement known as Pop Art. His works include the iconic painting of a Campbell's Soup Can, numerous silkscreen paintings, and the film Andy Warhol's Frankenstein (1973). Born in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, to Czech immigrant parents, Warhol had a relatively quiet childhood, although he showed early promise in art. After studying at the Carnegie Institute of Technology (now Carnegie Mellon University), he moved to New York City in 1949, where he began working as a commercial artist. In the 1950s, he established himself as a successful illustrator, with clients such as Vogue and The New Yorker. In the early 1960s, Warhol began to produce paintings that would become synonymous with Pop Art. Using images from popular culture and everyday objects, he explored themes of mass production, consumerism, and celebrity. His work was exhibited in galleries and museums around the world, and in 1964, he founded the Andy Warhol Foundation for the Visual Arts. Throughout his career, Warhol also worked in film, television, and music, producing and directing several underground films, and collaborating with artists such as the Velvet Underground and Nico. In 1968, he was shot by radical feminist Valerie Solanas, which left him critically injured. Despite the shooting, Warhol continued to work and maintain his socialite lifestyle in New York City until his death in 1987.

Statistical Physics.passage: Statistical physics is a branch of physics that studies the behavior of large ensembles of particles, typically in the context of thermodynamics and statistical mechanics. It focuses on the development and application of mathematical tools that enable the prediction of the properties of systems with a large number of particles, such as gases, liquids, and solids. In particular, it investigates the properties of systems at the macroscopic scale, including the behavior of phase transitions, the nature of critical phenomena, and the principles governing the transport of heat and mass. The foundations of statistical physics were laid by scientists such as James C. Maxwell, Ludwig Boltzmann, and Josiah Willard Gibbs, who contributed essential insights into the understanding of thermodynamic processes and the behavior of systems near phase transitions.

Pierre Curie.passage: Pierre Curie (1859–1906) was a French physicist and chemist who pioneered research on radioactivity. He was the first person to win Nobel Prizes in two different scientific fields: physics and chemistry. In 1903, he was awarded the Nobel Prize in Physics, along with his brother, Marie Curie, and Henri Becquerel, for their research on radiation. He later won the Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 1911, along with his wife, Marie Curie, and the American chemist, Irving Langmuir, for their work on the isolation of radioactive isotopes. Pierre Curie died in 1906, at the age of 46, from a fall off a horse while on a research trip. He was buried in Paris, France, alongside his wife, Marie Curie, who died in 1934. the Red Cross.passage: The International Red Cross and Red Crescent Movement is an international humanitarian movement with its origins in the early 19th century. It is best known for its role in providing emergency assistance to war-affected civilians, but it also provides assistance in peacetime. The Movement is composed of several distinct organizations, the most prominent of which is the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC). The ICRC is a neutral, independent, and non-governmental organization, which provides humanitarian aid and assistance to war-affected populations, and it also works to promote and strengthen the rules of war. The Movement's emblem, the red cross or red crescent, is a symbol of protection and assistance for war-affected civilians, and it is also used to mark humanitarian relief items, such as medical supplies and food. The Movement's work is guided by the principles of humanity, impartiality, neutrality, and independence, as set out in the Geneva Conventions and its Additional Protocols. The International Red Cross and Red Crescent Movement is a recipient of the Nobel Peace Prize, which it shared with the International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies in 1963.

Diego Rivera.passage: Diego Rivera (1886-1957) was a prominent Mexican painter and a leading figure in the Mexican Mural Renaissance. His works, which included murals, frescoes, and oil paintings, were characterized by their bold colors, strong social messages, and their blend of modern art and traditional Mexican culture. Rivera's most famous works included the Detroit Institute of Arts' 'Detroit Industry' murals, the 'Battle of the Alamo' mural at the San Antonio Museum of Art, and the 'Flower of Life' mural at the National Palace in Mexico City. Apart from his artistic achievements, Rivera was also known for his political activism and his support for the Soviet Union and the Cuban Revolution. Throughout his career, Rivera's work had a significant impact on the development of public art in the 20th century, influencing many artists, including Jackson Pollock and Mark Rothko.

Mexico.passage: Mexico (Spanish: México) is a country located in North America.
